history.content: The quality of the research you do will matter far more than your grades in terms of grad school applications, especially if the rest of your grades are in the A-/A/A+ range

children.subject: Is this more for PhD programs or for any and all graduate school, including terminal MS or MEng degrees?
All graduate school, including terminal MS. I am not sure whether I would pursue PhD or not.
But I want to ensure my record is steady for applying to higher education

(I guess I should've clarified terminal MS through the PhD program, sorry, two comments above sounds like it contradicted the post itself oops. I don't have application for grad school fully planned, just the potential to do it).
(Or *PhD programs with MS degree awarded while in it, just higher education)

Usually how terminal masters admissions work is they primarily look at your GPA and GRE scores (with a few exceptions), since many of these masters programs are just more CS courses so that people can find a job in industry. If you are getting not many B's, then you should get into most masters programs like this, although the question is why would you want to do this coming from Cal.

The exceptions are masters at places like Cal and UW (I think) where the masters are research oriented masters, but you can essentially think of admissions for this like an easier PhD program; the statements about grades still hold, but research is less significant in the sense that the standard applicants usually doesn't have as much research; i.e. you can get into these programs with good grades and letters of recs describing your good performance in a specific class and having little research, but you can't get into a top PhD program if you have little to no research.
I see, thank you for this information.

Usually people care about a trend rather than individual grades; if B+'s are rare on your transcript (there's no hard number but a prof told me a few are fine as long as you are talking hard course loads) you have nothing to worry about. If you consistently get in the B/B+ range then you'd start to have a problem. To give a little more context to the student answer though, research matters far more than grades, but low grades will hurt you in admissions significantly.

Thanks for this information and perspective. I may apply to competitive PhD (or definitely masters programs) in ML/AI which is why I was concerned about grades. I have conducted research starting from this semester, but because of recently getting involved in research I have not planned ahead yet.

I'm a PhD student here and I got a B+ in CS 70. I also got B's in half my other courses. And a couple C's too. Grades are useful for admissions insofar as they predict good work ethic or intelligence, but if you have better indicators of those qualities (like research or teaching or good rec letters) then they don't really matter.

history.content:
I was content with performance in the class, until I had bad luck and did not do so well on the 70 final and I wasn't sure if I ended with an A- or a B+, I ended with the latter grade, and I am so shocked at the disjointness of this to the point where none of my friends know at all. I don't believe this represents what I know about math or the class though. I entered the semester expecting A in CS70, and was previously enrolled in another CS upper div too, I guess life happens (which I have to take care of once I'm back at school). Interestingly I also thought I did pretty badly on the 61C final that happened earlier, and I ended up doing 1 SD above average for them because everyone did badly.

I am pursuing artificial intelligence and machine learning research this coming semester, and I'm taking math based courses. I was wondering how top graduate school will view a B+ in discrete math, I got advice from a CS advisor here who said that because it's a lower div it won't matter as much as upper div. 

I've also known that in high school, one person I knew got an unfair B in an equivalent to AP physics but did very very well in achieving what he wanted to get to for college. So I believe I have time to make my graduate school app as competitive as possible and disregard this grade.

I have a similar question for masters programs as well
